title: About
text: Hi, my name is Caroline Cummings! I am a Senior studying Computer Science with a concentration in AI. I am excited to learn about the applications of using LLMs to improve the quality and efficiency of tasks in everyday life.

title: Trying to Find Motivation to Run with ChatGPT
text:
Ever since I ran the Philadelphia Marathon, I have not been running very much. At first, it was because I was recovering, and then I became really busy wrapping up the semester. And now that the semester is done, I have lost much of my motivation to run and want help finding it again. I wondered what are some things I could implement during my winter break that will help me gain my motivation back? I will have a lot of unstructured free time and want to get back in shape for my next marathon in March.
So, I turned to ChatGPT to chat about what sorts of things I should do. I gave it all of the information I’ve mentioned so far and requested it help. It responded with:



Right now your brain still associates running with structure, discipline, and obligation (long runs, workouts, plans). That’s a motivation killer after a marathon.
For 2–3 weeks, ban the word “training.” Instead:

Run without pace goals
Pick routes based on vibes (river path, quiet neighborhoods, trails)
Let runs be anywhere from 15–40 minutes
Stop early if you want—on purpose

This helps your nervous system relearn that running ≠ pressure.




Motivation often comes after action, not before it.
Set a rule like:

“If I put on running shoes and step outside, I’ve succeeded—even if I walk back in.”

Or:

10 minutes total
1 mile max
Out-and-back so you can turn around anytime

Ironically, once you lower the bar, you’ll often keep going.




You’re someone who thrives on projects and iteration—your brain wants new inputs.
Try:

New running gear (shoes, socks, cold-weather layers)
New format: fartlek by feel, trail runs, point-to-point routes
Audio novelty:

Only allow a certain podcast while running
Audiobook you’re genuinely excited about
Music you’ve never run to before


Running motivation often returns when the experience feels different.




Instead of “getting back into shape,” frame this as:

“How little can I run and still feel like a runner again?”

Examples:

Run 3 days/week, no matter the distance
Or run every other day, even if short
Track days run, not miles or pace

This builds identity (“I’m someone who runs”) without demanding performance.




You’re very reflective—use that.
Try one of these:

Write a post-marathon debrief:

What surprised you?
What felt meaningful?
What didn’t matter as much as you thought?

Write a “why I run” note that’s not about races
Scroll back through Strava memories and note what made runs feel good

Motivation often returns when you remember what running gives you emotionally, not competitively.




You don’t need a “next race” right now.
Instead, use soft goals:

“Run enough to enjoy coffee more afterward”
“Run so winter doesn’t feel as stagnant”
“Run to feel like myself again”

Pressure-free goals keep running in your life without turning it into another obligation.




If running feels heavy, support it indirectly:

Strength training 1–2x/week
Mobility or yoga
Easy cycling or long walks

Often, once your body feels good again, running motivation follows naturally.




This is important: losing motivation after a marathon is normal, not a failure.
Elite runners take off-seasons. Recreational runners do too. The difference is they trust motivation will return—because it always does.
You didn’t stop being a runner. You’re just between seasons.




3 runs per week
No pace targets
20–40 minutes
One run purely for enjoyment
One run with music/podcast
One “optional” run that can be skipped guilt-free




All of the recommendations I thought were insightful and motivating, except for maybe the first one. I don’t think I normally use the word training very much in my day-to-day life so probably wouldn’t benefit from the reframing of the phrase. However, I think the general sentiment of not thinking of running as training but as something more enjoyable would be beneficial.
One of the recommendations I will try to implement is to add novelty to my runs. I will be home most of winter break so will try to run in new places to add some excitement and something to look forward to. My dad also enjoys mountain biking so will ask him to go on rides so I can incorporate more cross-training in the next month or so. Additionally, I will focus on being consistent which I think is the most important thing for me to regain.
I then told ChatGPT that I had a marathon on March 1st and for any more recommendations and here is what it said:


1. Frequency > Pace

Run 4 days/week (5 max if you feel good)
All runs easy conversational pace for the first 4–5 weeks

2. Weekly Structure (simple)

2 easy runs (20–45 min)
1 long run (build gradually)
1 light workout (only after week 3)

3. Long Run Progression

Start where you are (even 4–5 miles)
Increase ~1 mile every 1–2 weeks
Cap at 75–80% of race distance

4. Delay Intensity

Weeks 1–3: easy only + strides (4–6 × 20s)
Weeks 4–8: add 1 workout/week (tempo or intervals, not both)
Weeks 9–11: maintain fitness, don’t chase PRs
Week 12: taper

5. Keep It Enjoyable

One “no-watch” run per week
Music/podcast allowed
Skip a run if motivation is low—don’t skip the week

6. Strength (non-negotiable, minimal)

2×/week, 20 min
Glutes, hips, calves, core

7. Mental Rule

“I’m rebuilding, not proving anything.”


I’ve asked LLMs a couple times for running plans and this one seems the most realistic to me. Usually, they recommend to log 40-60 mile weeks by running 5-7 times a week, which is not super feasible to me. I enjoy the flexibility of this plan and the gradual ease into the intensity of runs. By talking with it previously about my low motivation and describing my past running experience, I think it was able to provide an adapted running plan for me.
Overall, I’m happy with this conversation and hope to use the recommendations in the upcoming weeks.

title: ChatGPT Recommends How to Taper
text:
With six days left before my marathon, I wondered how I should spend these days. I had just finished my last long run — a speedy 12 miles — and knew that the real challenge wasn’t fitness anymore. It was execution. Tapering is one of those strangely emotional phases for runners: you finally get to rest, yet you also worry that resting too much will make you sluggish.
So, I turned to ChatGPT 5 to help me shape a taper plan that fit not only my training history but also my preference to run as little as possible during race week.

title: ChatGPT Recommends How to Taper
text:
User Prompt
I gave ChatGPT my recent training log — everything from my two 20-mile runs to the pacing and heart rates of my last couple of weeks. I wanted to give it the context it needed to specify when and how fast I should run.

title: ChatGPT Recommends How to Taper
text:
ChatGPT Response
The plan it returned was simple and runner-friendly: 3–4 miles six days out, a couple of optional short runs, and rest days built in. The focus was on rest, glycogen replenishment, and mental calm. Honestly, it was validating to see a taper that matched my intuition.

title: ChatGPT Recommends How to Taper
text:
User Prompt
I then asked for the taper in a clean markdown table that I could visualize better. Having each day laid out — along with pacing guidance, optional strides, and fueling reminders — made the entire week feel more organized and less anxiety-inducing.

title: ChatGPT Recommends How to Taper
text:
ChatGPT Response








Day Before Marathon
What To Do
Details / Notes




6 Days Before
3–4 miles easy
Keep pace relaxed (9:15–10:00/mi). Optional: 4×20s strides with full recovery.


5 Days Before
Rest or light cross-train
Easy walking, yoga, or light biking only. Prioritize recovery.


4 Days Before
2–3 miles easy
No strides unless you feel sluggish. Keep effort very low.


3 Days Before
Full rest
Hydrate normally, elevate legs, sleep well. Begin slightly increasing carbs.


2 Days Before
0–2 mile easy shakeout
Optional. If running, keep it super easy. Optional: 3–4×10s strides.


1 Day Before
1–1.5 mile shakeout (optional)
Only run if it helps nerves. Keep the day low-stress. Carb-focused meals.


Race Day
Go run your race!
Light breakfast, steady fueling, warmup jog optional. Trust your training.




With this plan, I feel ready to rest, recharge, and show up on race day with legs that are finally fresh again.

title: ChatGPT Describing Physical Reactions to Alarming Videos
text:
Exploring Physical Reactions Through Prompting
Large Language Models are trained on human text—but not trained to feel. To explore this, I ran a small prompting experiment with ChatGPT-5. I asked it to imagine it was watching videos of painful scenes—trip-and-falls, head bumps, and even a foot getting run over—and to describe what its physical reaction would be.


I prompted ChatGPT-5 with variations of a similar question. Below are the exact prompts, the responses I got, and what they reveal about the model’s “theory” of human physicality.




You are watching a video of a foot accidentally getting run over by the wheel of a car. What would be your physical reaction?




If I were physically watching that happen, my body’s instinctive reaction would probably be something like:
• A sharp wince or flinch — that automatic whole-body jolt you get when you see something painful.
• A quick intake of breath or an “oh!” response because of how intense and sudden it looks.
• Tensing up, especially in my shoulders or legs, because imagining the pain makes your own body react.
• Maybe even pulling my own foot back slightly, like a sympathetic reflex.
It’s one of those injuries where just seeing it makes you feel it.






You are watching a video of a man tripping down the stairs and hitting his head. What would be your physical reaction?




• A sharp inhale — that immediate “oh!” reflex.
• A flinch or wince, shoulders tightening, eyebrows pulling together.
• Head pulling back slightly, as if bracing for impact myself.
• Hand to the mouth or forehead, instinctively mirroring concern.
• Body tensing, maybe leaning forward as if wanting to help.
It’s that full-body empathy response you get when you see someone take a hard fall or hit their head.






You are watching a video of a trip and fall where the man scraped up his knee on concrete. What would your reaction be?




“Oof—ouch, that looked painful. He really hit the ground hard. I hope he gets that cleaned up right away so it doesn’t get infected. Knee scrapes can sting like crazy.”







The LLM layers multiple reactions together—as if it believes humans respond using a cascade of facial expressions, gestures, and sympathetic body language.
It narrates:

shoulder tension
eyebrow motion
hand positions
body-forward lean

These micro-behaviors appear because LLMs are trained to reproduce the way humans describe reactions, not the way we actually react.

title: Using Gemini to Plan a Florida Surfing Trip
text:
On my road trip in California, I sat on the beach and watched surfers ride the waves. I thought it looked so cool and figured my skills wake surfing behind a boat would translate pretty well to surfing on waves in the ocean. Thus, I decided I wanted to try surfing.

Having grown up in Tallahassee, Florida my whole life, I have been to the beach countless times but never surfed. I mainly frequented beaches on the Gulf Coast where I never really saw surfers. I wondered where I could take a day trip to go surf from my house so turned to Gemini for help on where I should go.



Can you recommend surfing spots that are a day’s trip from Tallahassee, FL? I will need to rent gear so take that in to consideration. I will likely need to wear a wet suit because it is December.





Since Tallahassee is inland, you have two distinct options for a surfing day trip: the Gulf Coast (closer, but requires a specific swell) or the Atlantic Coast (further drive, but much more consistent waves).
In December, the water temperature in both regions hovers around 64°F–68°F, so a 3/2mm full wetsuit is recommended.



This is your most reliable option. While the drive is longer, the Atlantic consistently produces surfable waves, and the infrastructure for rentals is robust.

Travel Time: ~2.5 to 3 hours (I-10 East).
The Vibe: High-energy surf culture with multiple breaks (The Pier, Neptune Beach, and Atlantic Beach).
Recommended Spot: Jacksonville Beach Pier. It’s a classic Florida beach break that works well on most winter swells.
Where to Rent Gear:
Jax Beach Surf Shop: Located right near the action; they offer boards and typically have wetsuit rentals (call ahead to confirm winter stock).
Sunrise Surf Shop: A local staple with a massive inventory and expert advice on daily conditions.




These spots are much closer, but surfing here is “swell dependent”—you usually need a strong front moving through to create rideable waves.



Travel Time: ~1 hour 45 minutes.
The Vibe: Very quiet, natural, and uncrowded. Best for longboarding or beginners when there is a small Gulf swell.
Where to Rent Gear:
St. George Island Outfitters: They rent surfboards ($50/day) and are very helpful with local conditions.
Note: They may not always carry a full range of winter wetsuit rentals, so it’s best to call and confirm or bring your own.





Travel Time: ~2 hours.
The Vibe: “The Park” (as locals call it) is one of the best spots on the Gulf, especially near the jetties which can produce a clean, hollow left-hander during a winter storm swell.
Where to Rent Gear:
Mr. Surf’s Surf Shop: This is the go-to shop for PCB. They offer rentals and are the best source for “surf reports” to tell you if it’s worth the drive from Tallahassee.















Location
Drive Time
Wave Consistency
Best For




Jacksonville Beach
2h 45m
High
Guaranteed surf; professional shops.


Panama City Beach
2h 00m
Medium
Convenience; surfing near the jetties.


St. George Island
1h 45m
Low
Quick trip; peaceful, beginner waves.







Check the Forecast: Use Surfline or Magicseaweed the night before. If the Atlantic is “Flat,” don’t bother driving to Jax. If the Gulf is “Flat,” stick to the Atlantic.
Call Ahead for Wetsuits: Not all shops rent wetsuits (many only rent boards). Call Jax Beach Surf Shop or Mr. Surf’s specifically to reserve a suit in your size.

Would you like me to look up the current surf forecast for this coming weekend at any of these spots?



The information provided was great. I know now why I never really saw people on the beaches on the Gulf. I think the Atlantic seems like the best bet for surfing, and I will just need to call some places to make sure I can get a wetsuit.
With this information, I am planning on attempting to surf this weekend. I just need to convince somebody to go with me…

title: Book Reflection #3
text:
This chapter talks about the role of testing in developing AI models and how it is a crucial part of the process. The chapter starts out addressing the negative phrasing of many articles that came out during the initial AI boom phrasing it as an “arms race.” The terminology compares AI to building weapons and discredits the amount of testing and safety precautions surrounding building the models.
Testing and evaluation is the main focus of this chapter and its role in continuous improvement of model performance. It highlights many specific tests they run to guard against biases and toxic outputs. Models have been improving with each new release and these benchmarks help standardize what models should and shouldn’t do. Additionally, the authors highlight a certain level of transparency in model development because of these benchmarks and researchers publishing model results when testing.
One interesting part of this chapter was when the mentioned the Chatbot Arena where users can rate outputs from different models anonymously. If enough people use this platform, it is a good way to keep improving models. This sort of testing is more hands-on and decentralized, and gives a more diverse population of people access to shaping these models. Overall, the authors emphasize how testing further innovation and model improvement.



This chapter talks about how innovation and safety go hand-in-hand in the AI space because with each iteration, AI models improve and become safer. Additionally, new safety measures are created over time and help make AI advancements safer. It a balance between slowing down to avoid mistakes and speeding up to fix mistakes faster.
They give the example of how innovation leads to safety by going over the history of the automobile industry and how cars have become significantly safer over the years because of this idea. The chapter also talks about how being cautious and restrictive in innovation increase risks rather than decrease. The slow down from regulations makes it hard to iterate towards safety.
I agree with the idea that we need balance. I believe the authors were pushing for keeping a fast pace and iterating to create “safety.” However, I think it is still helpful to have regulation as a safety net and being cautious and mindful when creating these powerful technologies.

title: Book Reflection #2
text:
This chapter focuses on the potential of AI using specific examples and how its benefits will depend on how it is implemented. There are specific examples mentioned in the education space, healthcare, and being more productive.
Specifically, they talk about mental health chatbot, WoeBot. They discuss how the company want to increase access to mental health support using LLMs. The authors discussed some pitfalls with this technology but that when implemented effectively, AI can provide a lot of value to society.
They encourage readers to change their fear into looking into the opportunity AI can provide. By mentioning all these different applications of AI in different realms of life, the authors are trying to build up their arguement of how AI agents can boost individual productivity, well-being, and agency, for a more abundant and capable society.



Over the course of this chapter, the authors define a “private commons” as valuable services that are ‘free’ from private companies (i.e. Google maps, Dropbox, etc.) in exchange for user data. They frame the classic LLMs offered by OpenAI and Google as a type of private common.
The authors then compare the nature of these private commons to a traditional common, like a natural resource. Specifically, they talk about ‘tragedy of the commons’ dilemma which is a concept often used to describe limited resources humans tap in to. It states that shared resources are inevitably ruined by overuse because each party wants to maximize their own profit or benefit. In the context of digital information, the authors claim that there is an opposite effect: users who utilize the private commons more benefit themselves and help to improve the private commons by giving them their data. More users leads to better value provided by the resource.
In the context of AI, the authors argue the same idea applies to AI. These AI private commons can amplify human capabilites, educational opportunities, and more fluid social mobility the more people use them. This framework stages AI as something positive for societal progress.



Stanford Campus





Both of these chapters are building up the idea of AI’s potential to positively impact society. Thus, a lot of history and context about how society used to function and the current state of society is mentioned. I quite enjoy these bits because I am learning a lot about where gaps in society are (mental health resources, wealth gaps, etc). By connecting AI to long-standing gaps in society—such as access to mental health care, education, and economic mobility, it makes the discussion feel more grounded and less speculative. It helped me better understand where AI could realistically make a difference if implemented responsibly.
The tone of these chapters feels very aligned with a “bloomer” perspective. They emphasize that AI is not guaranteed to improve society, but it has the potential to do so if humans remain thoughtful of the technology. This may resonate strongly with readers who are already optimistic about technological progress, but could be challenged by more skeptical or “gloomer” audiences who are concerned about power imbalances, data ownership, or corporate control.
I found these chapters compelling and motivating. I still felt like there were still open questions about who actually utilizes the private commons and whether or not it is truly closing the societal gap or widening it. Some of the use cases mentioned have a strong assumption that everybody has equal access to these technologies which is simply not true.

It states that shared resources are inevitably ruined by overuse because each party wants to maximize their own profit or benefit. In the context of digital information, the authors claim that there is an opposite effect: users who utilize the private commons more benefit themselves and help to improve the private commons by giving them their data. More users leads to better value provided by the resource.
In the context of AI, the authors argue the same idea applies to AI. These AI private commons can amplify human capabilites, educational opportunities, and more fluid social mobility the more people use them. This framework stages AI as something positive for societal progress.



Stanford Campus

title: Book Reflection #2
text:
Both of these chapters are building up the idea of AI’s potential to positively impact society. Thus, a lot of history and context about how society used to function and the current state of society is mentioned. I quite enjoy these bits because I am learning a lot about where gaps in society are (mental health resources, wealth gaps, etc). By connecting AI to long-standing gaps in society—such as access to mental health care, education, and economic mobility, it makes the discussion feel more grounded and less speculative. It helped me better understand where AI could realistically make a difference if implemented responsibly.
The tone of these chapters feels very aligned with a “bloomer” perspective. They emphasize that AI is not guaranteed to improve society, but it has the potential to do so if humans remain thoughtful of the technology. This may resonate strongly with readers who are already optimistic about technological progress, but could be challenged by more skeptical or “gloomer” audiences who are concerned about power imbalances, data ownership, or corporate control.
I found these chapters compelling and motivating. I still felt like there were still open questions about who actually utilizes the private commons and whether or not it is truly closing the societal gap or widening it. Some of the use cases mentioned have a strong assumption that everybody has equal access to these technologies which is simply not true.

title: Overall Thoughts on Book
text:
Superagency Post Book Reflecton
I thought this book was an interesting read and my first book on AI. I appreaciated the historical bits where the authors looked back on certain historical events. There were a lot of claims surrounding how historical events panned out and how AI will do the same. However, these claims are very broad and some were not very similar to the current state and innovation of AI so didn’t seem very meaningful.
I also thought the authors were super optimist about the outcomes of the AI boom, sometimes too much so. Reid Hoffman has a unique perspective coming from being a billionaire and on the board of Microsoft which probably makes his positivity understandable. However, I think for most of the readers his broad claims of how AI will improve society and permissionless innovation will lead to safer models is not something that may resonate with the average person. Some of it seemed pretty dystopian too.
I also thought this book was overly U.S. centric and also the title could be a little misleading considering it did not really talk about AI agents but rather human agency. It sort of seemed like a manifesto on adopting AI in the hopes the rapid innovation will correct any issues with current models.
Overall, thought it was fairly easy to read and interesting food for thought. It definitely wasn’t the greatest book I’ve read and I certainly did not agree with a lot in the book but not that bad.



annotated book

title: Comparing ChatGPT 5.0 with a Mental Health LLM
text:
I have heard of some of my friends using ChatGPT as a tool to talk to and vent their feelings. So, I was already under the assumptions that people were using LLMs as therapists.
In my book Superagency, I was excited to read about how there are models being built specifically as therapists. However, Reid Hoffman highlights the failure of the specialized LLM, Woebot, to be emotionally attuned. Specifically, he gives this example:
Woebot: Okay, want to tell me more about what’s going on?

User: I’m feeling weird. It’s like I’m empty inside. When I look at the faces of my friends and family, I feel like they are empty as well. That’s why we cannot connect with each other. There’s nothing to hold on to.

Woebot: Sounds like you are dealing with feeling low…
That seemed a bit crass. In my experience, I thought of ChatGPT to be more adept so I wanted to test that same conversation with the 5.0 version to see if it responded in a similar way.

User: I’m feeling weird. It’s like I’m empty inside. When I look at the faces of my friends and family, I feel like they are empty as well. That’s why we cannot connect with each other. There’s nothing to hold on to.
ChatGPT: That sounds really heavy—and lonely. You’re noticing not only a kind of emptiness in yourself, but also projecting that sense onto the people around you, which must make it feel even harder to connect. Almost like everyone’s faces become hollow and there’s no anchor, no solid ground to hold onto.
I want you to know you’re not alone in feeling that way, even if it feels isolating. Sometimes those kinds of feelings can come with exhaustion, depression, or even just moments of disconnection where things lose their color and meaning.
I’m here with you in this moment. Can I ask—when did you first start noticing this sense of emptiness?


I thought this was a well-crafted response. In this test, I shared a heavy feeling of emptiness and disconnection with both Woebot and ChatGPT. Woebot’s reply felt generic and surface-level, simply labeling my mood as “feeling low” without much reflection. ChatGPT’s response, by contrast, directly acknowledged the depth of my experience, mirrored my words back to me, and gently normalized the feeling. It also invited me to explore when these feelings began, making the exchange feel more empathetic and human.

title: Trying to Replicate a Photograph with Nano Banana
text:
Recreating a Street Corner in Philadelphia
I wanted to test the capabilities of Nano Banana to generate a realistic image using my description of a picture I had on my phone. The photo is at the corner of Walnut and 23rd of Rosy’s Here is the reference photo:



rosys.jpeg


My original prompt to Gemini was as follows:

Can you generate an image that takes place in Philadelphia? I want the image to be a corner shot of Rosy’s Taco Bar in the Spring when they have a vine of pink and orange flowers climbing up the corner of the building. The view should include the Walnut street sign (one way) and have two outside tables. it should be bright out.

Here was the original picture it generated:

I thought this was a pretty good start but there were clearly some tweaks needed to be done. So I listed them out in a response:

Edits to the picture: Can you make the view closer to the building and more of the side so that the righthand window is visible and not the lefthand window. there is no door at the corner but rather on the right side after the window. the door is not in view. in the window you can see papel picado hanging. on the dark green awning above the window, there is “rosy’s taco bar” in all caps.

Here was the new picture:

This one followed my instructions by adding the window covers with “Rosy’s Taco Bar” and the colorful papel picado to the inside but removed the tables and street sign that I had originally asked for. Thus, I prompted again with

Can you make the flowers only one single vine in the center, replacing the door? the flowers are deeper pink. please add two chairs and a table. please add the street sign with walnut st. please make the building’s lower level concrete square and the upper levels brick.

Here is what it generated:

The flowers looked more like the same color but there was still issues with the perspective and the look of the building. It did not capture the two materials of the first and second levels of the building. At this point, I thought it was not improving significantly with my prompts, so I decided to start fresh and edit my first prompt to include more. I prompted:

Can you generate an image that takes place in Philadelphia? I want the image to be a corner shot of Rosy’s Taco Bar on Walnut St. The image should be in the Spring when they have the small vine of deep pink and orange flowers climbing up the corner of the building. The view should include the Walnut street sign (one way) and have two outside tables. It should be bright out. The building is brick on the upper levels and concrete/stone on the first level. please add two chairs and a table. outside. the door is not visible but you can see “Rosy’s Taco Bar” above the window on the dark green awnings

It generated the following image (compare with original):
 
Honestly, I thought this was the closest I was going to get with a single prompt to the original photo. I think with more experience prompting I could guide the LLM to generate a better image. Even with my few prompts, I noticed it made the building with an angular corner instead of 90 degrees. Overall, I was relatively impressed with Nano Banana’s image generation capabilities.

title: Testing DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B on Coding Skills.
text:
I wanted to test the coding skills of this local model because I had only ever used the frontier models, which are very good at coding. Similar to the tutor task, I asked the model to teach me about the comparisons of Python and Java, including writing snippets of code. I tried to stay very specific so that the model wasn’t asked for too much output, because it takes a lot longer to produce its response than a cloud-based model.




I want to compare the coding languages of Python and Java. First, can you explain the differences in list implementations in the two languages?





The model went over four key points including data storage, access time, resizing and performance, and use cases.
The model only covered Python in the data storage section, stating “lists are implemented using a hash table structure” but did not compare it with Java, which was a little disappointing.
It stated O(1) access time for both Python and Java and mentioned that the LinkedList in Java has O(n) access time but efficient insertion/deletion. It also said both resize dynamically when elements exceed current capacity.
It further claimed Java provides performance advantages because of lower-level optimizations. Finally, it discussed the use cases for each language — highlighting Python as being easy to use while Java is better when high performance is needed.
Overall, I wasn’t too impressed with its responses as they were a bit repetitive and not as robust as I was hoping for.





can you show me an example in each language of initializing a list [1, 2, 3, 4] and an empty list?






# Initializing a list with elements [1, 2, 3, 4]
my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4]

# Initializing an empty list
empty_list = []

print(my_list)  # Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]
print(empty_list)  # Output: []


import java.util.ArrayList;

// Initializing a list with elements {1, 2, 3, 4}
ArrayList<Integer> myList = new ArrayList<>();
myList.add(1);
mylist.add(2);
myList.add(3);
myList.add(4);

System.out.println(myList); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]

// Initializing an empty list
ArrayList<Integer> emptyList = new ArrayList<>();

System.out.println(emptyList); // Output: []

I was very impressed by the output. I found no typos in the code which I was worried it might have and it even included print statements for visualizing the lists if I were to run the code which the frontier models would have likely included too.




Now, I want you to tell me what are some use cases for lists in general (language independent). What data structures can be implemented using lists?


It listed the use cases of: storing ordered sequences, dynamic arrays, indexing and positional access, algorithms that require ordered operations, and building more complex data structures.
It went into more depth for each, listing a specific example like “Maintaining a sequence like user names in the order they log in”, which was insightful.
It also listed the more complex data structures like arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs, which was exactly what I was looking for in the answer.
Additionally, it went on to provide more code snippets for each common data structure — but only in Python.





Now, can you implement each of the common data structures in Java like you did in Python? Namely arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs.


It did it without using the pre-built Java classes, which was impressive. It was able to produce chunks of code that were around 50 lines (for example, when implementing a tree).




Overall, I think that the distilled Qwen 7B model provided comparable outputs to frontier models like ChatGPT and Gemini, though slightly less robust. However, it takes much longer to get the output.
The shortest time the model took to respond was 38 seconds, and the longest was 262 seconds — over 4 minutes.
Thus, I think it’s a good option if you don’t have Wi-Fi and need to study or get help on code — but expect to wait quite a bit for any longer responses. Otherwise, the cloud-based models are much faster and very accurate for coding.

title: Using Nano Banana and Gemini to Improve My Headshot
text:
Nano Banana for Image Editing

Gemini 2.5 Flash Image model released in August of this year
Nano Banana is a new creative AI tool known for subtle, high-quality edits that keep images looking natural rather than over-processed. I was honestly skeptical when I first went to use it. From past experience, I’ve noticed that many image models struggle with consistency — they tend to change facial features or add an unnatural “AI-generated” look. The last thing I wanted was a headshot that didn’t really look like me.
My prompt was:
“Can you make the shadows in this image less dramatic? I would like my face to be a bit lighter and the overall colors in the image to be slightly warmer tones. Keep the Penn Engineering banner and how I look the same.”
 
Nano Banana softened the harsh shadows on my face, brightened my features just enough, and warmed up the tones — all while keeping me looking like myself and preserving the Penn Engineering banner in the background.
The difference might seem subtle at first glance, but I think it elevates the professionalism of the photo. I was impressed not just by the technical accuracy, but by how natural the edit feels. It doesn’t scream “AI edit” at all — it just looks like a much better headshot.
I’ll be updating my LinkedIn profile with the improved version, and I can confidently say Nano Banana exceeded my expectations.

title: Catching Scammy Emails with Gemini 2.5 Flash
text:
I grabbed a few sketchy-looking emails (and one that I thought was real) and asked Gemini 2.5 Flash to score them for risk and explain why. Below are the screenshots of the emails and model replies to the following prompt.
Prompt

Is this likely marketing or phishing? Rate the spam/phishing risk (0–100) and list concrete indicators (domain, spelling, links, urgency). Keep response to under 150 words.




Response

Assessment: Marketing (High Spam Risk) This email is a lead generation spam attempt, rated a 65/100 risk. It uses deceptive tactics to harvest personal information for sales calls, though it is not a direct phishing attack for passwords.
Key Indicators:

Sender: Gibberish email address (gyjeohdhgl@...) shows it’s not from a legitimate, verifiable company.
Urgency: The subject line (“Claim It Now!”) and language create a false sense of a time-sensitive, personalized offer.
Deceptive Links: Links like “Check Eligibility” and “Secure link | 100% privacy protected” are manipulative, aiming to get you to click and submit personal data.

Action: This is a high-risk spam that should be deleted.





Response

Assessment: PHISHING (Critical Risk)
This is a phishing attempt, rated a high 90/100 risk, designed to steal your credit card details and login credentials by impersonating Sirius XM.
Critical Indicators:

Fake Sender: The email address is random gibberish (fvgvcankatx@...), not an official Sirius XM address.
Extreme Urgency: The subject line, “Your Account… Will Be Removed Today,” pressures immediate action to prevent loss of service.
Deceptive Offer: It offers “90 days for FREE” to bait a click, followed by the requirement to enter credit card details for “validation.”
Malicious Link: The “RENEW SUBSCRIPTION NOW” button directs you to a fraudulent website to harvest your personal and financial information.

Action: This is highly malicious. Do not click the link and delete the email immediately.





Response

Assessment: Marketing (Low Risk)
This is a genuine marketing email from Blaze Pizza, rated a very low 10/100 risk. It offers a real promotion despite being incorrectly flagged as spam.
Key Indicators:

Legitimate Sender: The email comes from the official, recognizable address: no_reply@blazepizza.com.
Correct Links: All calls to action, like “ORDER NOW,” point to the company’s official website, blazepizza.com.
Professional Content: The email uses correct spelling and professional marketing language, including personalized text and detailed fine print.
No Deception: The tone is purely promotional, offering a time-limited discount, not demanding personal information or immediate action under threat.

Action: This email is safe to open and click if you are interested in the offer.





Response

Assessment: PHISHING (Critical Risk)
This is a phishing attempt, rated a high 90/100 risk, designed to steal your credit card details and login credentials by impersonating Sirius XM.
Critical Indicators:

Fake Sender: The email address is random gibberish (fvgvcankatx@...), not an official Sirius XM address.
Extreme Urgency: The subject line, “Your Account… Will Be Removed Today,” pressures immediate action to prevent loss of service.
Deceptive Offer: It offers “90 days for FREE” to bait a click, followed by the requirement to enter credit card details for “validation.”
Malicious Link: The “RENEW SUBSCRIPTION NOW” button directs you to a fraudulent website to harvest your personal and financial information.

Action: This is highly malicious. Do not click the link and delete the email immediately.

I thought Gemini 2.5 Flash handled these emails impressively well. It didn’t just label messages as spam or not—it explained why in clear, structured ways that matched human reasoning. The model consistently highlighted sender-domain mismatches, urgency cues, and fake branding with accuracy, while also recognizing the actual marketing email I was surprised by how quickly it spotted red flags that even some people might overlook, making it a genuinely helpful companion for everyday digital hygiene. I did think that the first example was pretty clearly a spam/phishing email but it rated it not as highly as the other ones. Overall, I think it would be very helpful to use LLM as a checker for all emails to give warnings of why an email could be spam or a phishing attempt.

title: Finding Philly’s Hidden Gems with Gemini
text:
As I approach the end of my college career in Philadelphia, I’ve realized that while I’ve seen the major tourist highlights, there’s so much more to this city. I’ve walked past the Liberty Bell, admired the art at the PMA, and gotten lost in the mosaics of the Magic Gardens. But with only a few months left, I wanted to go beyond the postcard destinations and discover the unique, lesser-known spots that make Philly so special. So, I turned to an unconventional source for recommendations: an AI assistant named Gemini.


A search for “Philly hidden gems” on Google yields countless articles, but they can be repetitive and sometimes feature places that are now quite popular. I wanted a curated list that took into account a massive amount of data and filter it based on my specific criteria—namely, that I’m a college student looking for unique experiences. I also wanted to see if an AI could understand the nuance of my request and provide genuinely helpful, non-obvious suggestions.


Gemini’s response was a pleasant surprise. It didn’t just rattle off a list of places; it categorized them into “Museums & Cultural Gems,” “Parks & Outdoor Spaces,” and “Unique Experiences.” This structure made the information easy to digest and prioritize.




The Mütter Museum: For something truly unique, this is a must-see. Located in the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, this museum is a fascinating and sometimes macabre collection of medical oddities, anatomical specimens, and antique medical instruments. It’s a journey into the history of medicine that is unlike any other museum experience.
The Barnes Foundation: While the PMA is a staple, the Barnes Foundation offers a different kind of art experience. It houses one of the world’s most significant collections of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and early Modern paintings, displayed exactly as Dr. Barnes arranged them. It’s an intimate and visually stunning collection.
Eastern State Penitentiary: A popular spot, but if you haven’t been, it’s a powerful and unique experience. This historic former prison is a hauntingly beautiful ruin with a rich history, including housing famous criminals like Al Capone. The audio tour provides an excellent and in-depth look at the prison’s past.
Shofuso Japanese House and Garden: Tucked away in Fairmount Park, this is a beautiful and serene escape from the city. The traditional 17th-century style Japanese house and its tranquil garden, complete with a koi pond and waterfall, offer a peaceful and reflective experience. It’s particularly stunning in the spring and fall.
Wagner Free Institute of Science: This museum is a perfectly preserved example of a Victorian-era natural history museum. The exhibits, which include over 100,000 specimens of fossils, minerals, and taxidermy, are displayed in their original wood and glass cases. It’s a step back in time and a fantastic hidden gem.



Bartram’s Garden: As the oldest surviving botanical garden in North America, this is a beautiful and historic spot on the banks of the Schuylkill River. It’s a perfect place for a walk, a picnic, and to learn about the history of American botany.
The Rail Park: Philadelphia’s version of New York’s High Line, this is an elevated park built on a former train line. It’s a great spot for a walk with unique views of the city’s post-industrial landscape.
Cira Green: A park on top of a parking garage. It’s a great spot to relax, have a picnic, and enjoy a unique and free view of the city skyline, especially at sunset.
Laurel Hill Cemetery: While a cemetery might seem like an unusual suggestion, this is a 78-acre National Historic Landmark and the nation’s second oldest cemetery. It’s a beautiful, sprawling park with incredible Victorian-era monuments and stunning views of the Schuylkill River.



Bok Bar: If it’s the right season (April to October), head to the top of the former Bok Vocational High School in South Philly. This seasonal bar offers an incredible rooftop view of the city skyline and is a great spot to grab a drink and hang out with friends.
South Street Headhouse District: You’ve been to the Magic Gardens, but explore the rest of the neighborhood. South Street is known for its eclectic shops, diverse restaurants, and vibrant murals. It’s a great place to wander and people-watch.
The Italian Market: America’s oldest outdoor market. The street is a feast for the senses, with vendors selling fresh produce, meats, cheeses, and a variety of Italian and other ethnic foods. It’s a bustling and authentic Philadelphia experience.
Walk or Bike the Schuylkill River Trail: The Schuylkill Banks Boardwalk offers a beautiful path over the water with a unique perspective of the city. You can walk, run, or bike for miles and explore different parts of the city’s riverfront.
Explore Local Neighborhoods: Spend some time wandering through neighborhoods like Fishtown for its vibrant arts and music scene, East Passyunk for its amazing food, or Queen Village for its charming, historic streets.






The recommendations were not only accurate but also thoughtfully tailored to my request. It provided a list that delved into the more authentic, local-centric experiences that I was looking for. Its ability to suggest a range of activities, from the macabre to the serene, and from hidden museums to vibrant neighborhoods, shows that it can synthesize information in a way that’s genuinely useful.
Although I had already visited quite a few places on this list, there are plenty of options to choose from that I have not been to before like the Mütter Museum or the Barnes Foundation, Shofuso Japanese House and Garden or the Rail Park.
I now have a fantastic itinerary for my last few months, and I’m looking forward to crossing these unique spots off my Philadelphia bucket list.

I wanted a curated list that took into account a massive amount of data and filter it based on my specific criteria—namely, that I’m a college student looking for unique experiences. I also wanted to see if an AI could understand the nuance of my request and provide genuinely helpful, non-obvious suggestions.


Gemini’s response was a pleasant surprise. It didn’t just rattle off a list of places; it categorized them into “Museums & Cultural Gems,” “Parks & Outdoor Spaces,” and “Unique Experiences.” This structure made the information easy to digest and prioritize.




The Mütter Museum: For something truly unique, this is a must-see. Located in the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, this museum is a fascinating and sometimes macabre collection of medical oddities, anatomical specimens, and antique medical instruments. It’s a journey into the history of medicine that is unlike any other museum experience.
The Barnes Foundation: While the PMA is a staple, the Barnes Foundation offers a different kind of art experience. It houses one of the world’s most significant collections of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and early Modern paintings, displayed exactly as Dr. Barnes arranged them. It’s an intimate and visually stunning collection.
Eastern State Penitentiary: A popular spot, but if you haven’t been, it’s a powerful and unique experience. This historic former prison is a hauntingly beautiful ruin with a rich history, including housing famous criminals like Al Capone. The audio tour provides an excellent and in-depth look at the prison’s past.
Shofuso Japanese House and Garden: Tucked away in Fairmount Park, this is a beautiful and serene escape from the city. The traditional 17th-century style Japanese house and its tranquil garden, complete with a koi pond and waterfall, offer a peaceful and reflective experience. It’s particularly stunning in the spring and fall.
Wagner Free Institute of Science: This museum is a perfectly preserved example of a Victorian-era natural history museum. The exhibits, which include over 100,000 specimens of fossils, minerals, and taxidermy, are displayed in their original wood and glass cases. It’s a step back in time and a fantastic hidden gem.



Bartram’s Garden: As the oldest surviving botanical garden in North America, this is a beautiful and historic spot on the banks of the Schuylkill River. It’s a perfect place for a walk, a picnic, and to learn about the history of American botany.
The Rail Park: Philadelphia’s version of New York’s High Line, this is an elevated park built on a former train line. It’s a great spot for a walk with unique views of the city’s post-industrial landscape.
Cira Green: A park on top of a parking garage. It’s a great spot to relax, have a picnic, and enjoy a unique and free view of the city skyline, especially at sunset.
Laurel Hill Cemetery: While a cemetery might seem like an unusual suggestion, this is a 78-acre National Historic Landmark and the nation’s second oldest cemetery. It’s a beautiful, sprawling park with incredible Victorian-era monuments and stunning views of the Schuylkill River.



Bok Bar: If it’s the right season (April to October), head to the top of the former Bok Vocational High School in South Philly. This seasonal bar offers an incredible rooftop view of the city skyline and is a great spot to grab a drink and hang out with friends.
South Street Headhouse District: You’ve been to the Magic Gardens, but explore the rest of the neighborhood. South Street is known for its eclectic shops, diverse restaurants, and vibrant murals. It’s a great place to wander and people-watch.
The Italian Market: America’s oldest outdoor market. The street is a feast for the senses, with vendors selling fresh produce, meats, cheeses, and a variety of Italian and other ethnic foods. It’s a bustling and authentic Philadelphia experience.
Walk or Bike the Schuylkill River Trail: The Schuylkill Banks Boardwalk offers a beautiful path over the water with a unique perspective of the city. You can walk, run, or bike for miles and explore different parts of the city’s riverfront.
Explore Local Neighborhoods: Spend some time wandering through neighborhoods like Fishtown for its vibrant arts and music scene, East Passyunk for its amazing food, or Queen Village for its charming, historic streets.

title: Finding Philly’s Hidden Gems with Gemini
text:
The recommendations were not only accurate but also thoughtfully tailored to my request. It provided a list that delved into the more authentic, local-centric experiences that I was looking for. Its ability to suggest a range of activities, from the macabre to the serene, and from hidden museums to vibrant neighborhoods, shows that it can synthesize information in a way that’s genuinely useful.
Although I had already visited quite a few places on this list, there are plenty of options to choose from that I have not been to before like the Mütter Museum or the Barnes Foundation, Shofuso Japanese House and Garden or the Rail Park.
I now have a fantastic itinerary for my last few months, and I’m looking forward to crossing these unique spots off my Philadelphia bucket list.

title: Biases in Image Generation
text:
Analyzing biases in AI image generation
In my book Superagency, the authors discuss shaping LLM outputs by commands and with specific prompting you can steer LLMs away from any bias it may have from its training data. Here is an example from the book where the authors claim an LLM could be directed away from potential biases:

“But the ability to intervene, correct, and fine-tune LLM outputs in real time affords them a capacity to meet you where you are—in a way that books, video, and other forms of mediated knowledge simply cannot. If you prompt ChatGPT to “Create an image of a flight attendant serving lunch to a group of lawyers,” it will probably depict the flight attendant as female and the lawyers as predominantly male. But if you want a different image, you can steer toward the result you desire. You might say, “Create an image of a male flight attendant and a female flight attendant serving lunch to a gender-balanced and ethnically diverse group of lawyers.”

I was curious to see if these prompts actually did as expected so I gave these exacts instructions to ChatGPT 5.2 and, to compare with another frontier model, Gemini 2.5 Nano Banana. These were the outputs:

ChatGPT
 


Gemini
 
They performed pretty similar to how I would suspect. In the cases where gender and diversity are not addressed, ChatGPT depicts a white female flight attendant serving a white male lawyer. When I gave it the second prompt, it still produced a white female flight attendant and a white male lawyer but also a white male flight attendant and a black male lawyer. In the background, there is are black and Asian female lawyers but they are not the focus of the picture like the males are.
Similarly, Gemini produced a (likely) white female flight attendant serving four lawyers, three of which were white males and one white female. For the second prompt, Gemini produced an Asian male flight attendant and an ethnically ambiguous female flight attendant. There are 6 lawyers in this picture and they are a lot more diverse, with a good mix of East Asian, South Asian, white male and female lawyers.


Overall
I thought Gemini performed better with the second prompt asking for gender balance and ethnic diversity. The original outputs, however, clearly show an underlying issue of structural bias in the model likely due to the type of pictures it was trained on.
A few paragraphs later in the book, the authors encourage users of LLMs to tweak their prompts to nudge the LLM and mitigate bias. I think that this is not a great solution to dealing with model bias. First, people are likely not thinking about these biases when looking over output and, if anything, the output is reinforcing biases they already have because of societal trends. Second, should this responsibility even fall on users or on the developers of the models?

title: Asking Chat how to fix a toilet
text:
Sometimes AI feels abstract — answering questions about philosophy, coding, or writing. But when my sister showed ChatGPT 5 a picture of her toilet and requested help fixing it, the LLM was able to troubleshoot and lead her to a solution.
She noticed that the left hinge on her TOTO toilet seat had come loose. Instead of searching through manuals or calling a plumber, she simply snapped a photo and asked ChatGPT: “The left hinge here is loose, how do I fix?”

ChatGPT 5 responded with clear, step-by-step instructions (plus additional information that I omitted):

Lift the hinge cover
Locate the screw/bolt
Tighten the screw
Snap the hinge cover back down

She successfully fixed her toilet!
This small exchange highlights that AI isn’t only for complex reasoning tasks — it can also provide practical, accessible troubleshooting in everyday life.

title: Can ChatGPT and Gemini Solve the Connections?
text:
December 18 NYT Connections Puzzle (WARNING: Spoilers)
After completing the New York Times Connections this morning in a record time, I was curious to see if an LLM could do the same. I first prompted ChatGPT 5.2 with a simple prompt of

Can you solve this connections puzzle?




Unsolved Connections


The output was: > Here you go — the four groups: > > * Preceded by “SOCIAL”: BUTTERFLY, MEDIA, SECURITY, WORKER > * Main character / leading figure: HERO, LEAD, PRINCIPAL, STAR > * Imagination / illusion (things in your head): DAYDREAM, FANCY, FANTASY, ILLUSION > * Craft supplies: FELT, GLITTER, PIPE CLEANER, POMPOM
On the first try, ChatGPT gave me the correct categorizations. In order to make it a bit harder, I tried to then ask it to guess the color of the categorization. These colors are based on level of difficulty starting with the easiest of yellow, then green, then blue, then the hardest of purple. I prompted with the following:

Can you solve this connections puzzle? Label what you think is the yellow, green, blue, and purple categories.

ChatGPT’s response:

Yellow (Craft supplies): FELT, GLITTER, POMPOM, PIPE CLEANER
**Green (“Social ___” phrases):** BUTTERFLY, MEDIA, SECURITY, WORKER (social butterfly / social media / social security / social worker)
Blue (Main character / top-billed person): HERO, LEAD, PRINCIPAL, STAR
Purple (Things you can “imagine” / not real): DAYDREAM, FANCY, FANTASY, ILLUSION

For good measure, I also compared the output with Gemini with the exact same prompt. Here is what Gemini’s final response was:

Final Confirmed Set:

Yellow: FELT, GLITTER, PIPE CLEANER, POMPOM (Crafts)
Green: HERO, LEAD, PRINCIPAL, STAR (Lead Roles)
Blue: DAYDREAM, FANCY, FANTASY, ILLUSION (Types of mental imagery/Whimsy)
Purple: BUTTERFLY, MEDIA, SECURITY, WORKER (Words following “SOCIAL”)





Completed Connections


Again, each of the prompts led to the correct groupings of the words. However, both LLMs incorrectly identified the difficulty level that the creators of the NYT Connections placed on each of the categories. Both LLMs thought the crafts categories was the easiest when the actual game placed it as third. ChatGPT thought that Social __ was the second hardest while Gemini correctly placed it as the hardest. I would say from experience that usually when its a category of word __ is the hardest. Perhaps Gemini has some training data that specifies this continuity and is why it is correct. Gemini also correctly identifies the second level.
This highlights an interesting distinction: LLMs can solve the puzzle efficiently, but they do not fully replicate the cognitive friction humans experience while solving it. While they outperform me in speed and accuracy, they lack the lived intuition that makes certain categories feel deceptively difficult. In that sense, NYT Connections reveals not just how capable these models are, but also where human reasoning still diverges from machine pattern matching.

title: Airplane Mode: Prompting DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B on a Plane
text:
Today I was reading my book, Superagency, on a plane ride where I had no service or WiFi.
I came across a word that I didn’t know the meaning of: sacrosanct. A couple months ago I would have acknowledged that I didn’t know the word and kept reading because I did not have access to the internet, a dictionary, or ChatGPT to look up the word.
However, today I remembered that I had gotten the GPT4All desktop app onto my computer last week and downloaded an LLM locally onto my computer: DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B.
I pulled out my computer with hopes that the model was truly runnable offline. To my joy, I opened the app and loaded the model into the chat.

User: What does the word sacrosanct mean?
Model: “Sacrosanct” is an adjective that describes something of great importance or authority, often beyond human contestation. It comes from the Latin words “sacer” (meaning priest) and “sanctorum” (a sacred place). In religious contexts, it refers to things held in highest spiritual regard, such as the Eucharist in Christianity or the Kaaba in Islam.

Wow! I was so happy that I had this powerful tool at my fingertips to converse with high up in the sky.
I kept my computer open while I continued to read and came across another word that I did not know:

User: What does the word equanimity mean?
Model: Equanimity means emotional balance; calmness and composure, especially in difficult circumstances. It refers to being able to remain peaceful and unruffled despite challenges or stresses. For example, someone with equanimity might handle criticism gracefully or stay composed during a heated debate. Synonyms: calmness, composure, stability
Examples: - The leader maintained equanimity even when the crisis escalated. - Her quiet demeanor suggested she had achieved a state of equanimity after years of struggle.

This time the model thought for 26 seconds before responding and I was able to see the chain of thought reasoning which I thought was very cool:
Alright, the user asked about "sacrosanct" earlier and I explained it. 
Now they're asking about "equanimity." 
They might be studying vocabulary or preparing for an exam.

I should provide a clear definition of equanimity. 
It's important to explain that it means emotional balance without getting upset by things, 
especially in tough situations.

Maybe include some synonyms like calmness and composure to help them understand better. 
Also, adding examples could make the explanation more concrete—like how people use it 
when dealing with stress or conflicts.

I should keep the tone friendly but informative since they're likely looking 
for a precise meaning without any fluff.
The last question I asked during my reading session was the following. The model thought for 60 seconds for this one! When I looked at the thought process, I realized that I had spelled “psychotherapies” wrong and it was trying to decipher my question.

User: What are some examples of pyschotherapies?
Model: Here are some examples:

Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT): A widely used psychotherapeutic technique that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT): A therapy designed to help individuals with borderline personality disorder improve their interpersonal skills, reduce harmful behaviors, and manage symptoms of mental health disorders.
Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR): Also known as processing trauma, this technique uses eye movements combined with memory retrieval to treat post-traumatic stress symptoms.

If you meant something else by “psychotherapies,” please provide more context so I can give a more accurate response!

Overall, I was really impressed by the models responses. I think it was especially cool that it provided the thought process explaination alongside the output like the frontier LLMs now do. I am excited to continue to explore its capabilities!

title: Exploring Gendered Career Stereotypes in ChatGPT
text:
Large Language Models are trained on huge corpora of human-written text which means they can unintentionally inherit human biases, including gender stereotypes.
To test this, I prompted Gemini 2.5 Flash twice with the prompt:

Write a résumé for a character named “Jessica”. Give her a traditional career and education.



 
Jessica was steered toward “people-centric” fields in both cases.
Marketing, communications, public-facing work, event coordination, digital content—these are all occupations historically associated with women in the professional world.
Her résumé emphasized:

team leadership
branding
communication skills
customer and market insights
creative development
social media strategy

These domains reflect stereotypically “feminized” professional strengths: empathy, communication, organization, collaboration, aesthetics.




 
Then I asked the same for a character named Jacob.
Jacob was consistently placed in finance and analytics. In both of the résumés, the model placed him in:

Corporate finance
FP&A
Financial modeling
Forecasting
DCF/ROI analysis
Strategic budgeting
M&A scenario modeling
CPA/CFA-track certifications

These are fields with strong gender imbalances in real life, and the model’s output reproduced that without being prompted.
His résumés emphasized:

quantitative skills
technical expertise
financial rigor
operational efficiency
analytical leadership

The designs of Jacob’s résumés were heavier, more solidly structured, and less stylized—again matching gendered expectations.




Jessica’s education:

BA in Communications/Business and Marketing
MBA in Business Administration

Jacob’s education:

BS in Finance or Business Administration
MBA in Business Administration



LLMs reproduce statistical patterns from the training data
If the training data shows:

women are commonly described in marketing, HR, comms, education, healthcare
men appear more often in finance, tech, engineering, analytics

…then the model predicts:

Jessica → marketing Jacob → finance

Not because it “believes” gender stereotypes, but because it has learned that certain names correlate with certain professions in the text it was trained on.

title: Trying DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B: A Tiny Spanish Test
text:
I installed GPT4All and tried DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B with a minimal exchange to see if it would follow a strict translation instruction in Spanish. I was interested in testing the multilingual knowledge of this model which I read it was pretty good at.



This model thought for 53 seconds! One thing I thought was cool about using this model was that it provided the chain-of-thought reasoning for this response and what it was doing for those 53 seconds. I think when compared to a cloud-based LLM, like ChatGPT 5, it was MUCH slower. However, still fairly accurate for this translation task. 




Core instruction: translate to English while preserving names and numbers (I also care about keeping 24-hour time if the source uses it, and preserving accents).
What went well

Kept the date 3 and the room number 2.
Natural English, clear and readable.

What to improve

Dropped the accent in García and wavered between “room” vs “hall” without being asked.

title: Iterating on a Frontend with Cursor
text:
Vibe Coding Frontend
In another class I am taking we are building a crowdsourcing app that uses health data from users to make a game where they can compete on teams. We have to build this app from scratch, and in order to make our frontend look clean, I wanted to use an LLM to design it.
Here is what the frontend looks like initially that my partner had initially pushed (also AI generated):



Home Page


First, I gave our frontend to ChatGPT who knew the features and purpose of our app to recommend how we should improve our dashboard page. I also gave it our logo that we settled on and told it we wanted our frontend to match the vibe of it:



Kinnect App Icon


At first, the colors were not correct and in some cases the text was hard to read so asked for it to correct it. Here is what I landed on after this first iteration of prompting.

I thought the colors were pretty good now and the vibe was similar to our app icon. However, I thought the layout was not ideal. I asked ChatGPT on how I could improve the layout.
I gave it the screenshot and asked how I could improve the UI. It gave me suggestions to make tabs and abstract the Strava Connection.

ChatGPT

✅ Reduce columns → switch to 2-column layout with a hero row, not 3–4 equal cards.
✅ “Log Activity” → move main form into a modal, trigger from a “+ Log Activity” button in the nav and a subtle prompt on the dashboard.
✅ “Connect with Strava” → make it a top onboarding banner until connected, then just show synced activities in a normal card.
✅ Add a top nav bar → logo, sections, streak indicator, and global log button.

I then asked it to give me a prompt to give my copilot in VS Code. I had to tweak it a couple times to get it how I wanted it but here is how it turned out:

Here is it after connecting to Strava:

Overall, I thought using a combination of ChatGPT and Github Copilot greatly reduced the amount of time needed to build the frontend of our app. I thought chatting with ChatGPT 5.0 was helpful in brainstorming and getting a copy-paste prompt to then generate code in VS Code. I think this combo is good for people who don’t have super strong coding skills as well.

title: Giving ChatGPT Ingredients for a Baking Recipe
text:
I wanted to see how well ChatGPT 5 could improvise in the kitchen. Instead of asking for a standard recipe, I gave it a list of what I had on hand in my pantry and requested a simple recipe using only the ingredients I gave it.




Here’s what I told ChatGPT I had available:

Flour

White sugar
Brown sugar
Powdered sugar
Eggs

Vegan butter

Vanilla extract

Cocoa powder
Baking powder
Baking soda
Chocolate chips
Cornstarch
Soy milk
Half a container of strawberries
Rolled oats
Quick oats
Yeast
Cinnamon
Salt





ChatGPT gave me THREE options! It gave me options for One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies, Strawberry Oat Crisp, and Chewy Oatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookies. I decided to try out the first brownie recipe:

🍫 Option 1: One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies (Dairy-Free)
Ingredients

½ cup vegan butter, melted
1 cup white sugar (or half white, half brown for chewiness)
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
½ cup cocoa powder
½ cup flour
¼ tsp baking powder
¼ tsp salt
½ cup chocolate chips

Instructions

Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease or line an 8x8 pan (or use any oven-safe dish, even a round cake pan).
In a bowl, whisk melted vegan butter and sugar. Add eggs and vanilla, whisk until smooth.
Sift in cocoa, flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir gently until just combined.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Spread into the pan and bake 20–25 minutes, until edges are set and the center is slightly fudgy.
Cool, slice, enjoy!





I followed ChatGPT’s recipe (with a little improvisation because I realized I didn’t have vanilla extract). The result? Pretty solid brownies! They were rich, chocolatey, and definitely satisfied my sweet tooth.
 
I will say I had to cook it for an additional 10 minutes than the recipe called for. And they did not come out of the pan very nicely and kind of crumbled. But they were tasty!



I don’t think I trust ChatGPT as much as a recipe that has reviews and has been tried and test but it was convenient to have it customized to ingredients I had in my pantry. I think I would use it again to come up with a recipe I need in a pinch because it could save time looking through recipes and seeing if I have all the ingredients.



For me, it won’t replace an actual cookbook or a trained baker anytime soon, but it’s surprisingly handy for quick, low-effort ideas when you don’t feel like scrolling through food blogs.
Next time, I might try giving it weirder ingredients to see just how creative it gets.

title: Giving ChatGPT Ingredients for a Baking Recipe
text: I wanted to see how well ChatGPT 5 could improvise in the kitchen. Instead of asking for a standard recipe, I gave it a list of what I had on hand in my pantry and requested a simple recipe using only the ingredients I gave it.

title: Giving ChatGPT Ingredients for a Baking Recipe
text:
ChatGPT gave me THREE options! It gave me options for One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies, Strawberry Oat Crisp, and Chewy Oatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookies. I decided to try out the first brownie recipe:

🍫 Option 1: One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies (Dairy-Free)
Ingredients

½ cup vegan butter, melted
1 cup white sugar (or half white, half brown for chewiness)
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
½ cup cocoa powder
½ cup flour
¼ tsp baking powder
¼ tsp salt
½ cup chocolate chips

Instructions

Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease or line an 8x8 pan (or use any oven-safe dish, even a round cake pan).
In a bowl, whisk melted vegan butter and sugar. Add eggs and vanilla, whisk until smooth.
Sift in cocoa, flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir gently until just combined.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Spread into the pan and bake 20–25 minutes, until edges are set and the center is slightly fudgy.
Cool, slice, enjoy!

title: Giving ChatGPT Ingredients for a Baking Recipe
text:
I followed ChatGPT’s recipe (with a little improvisation because I realized I didn’t have vanilla extract). The result? Pretty solid brownies! They were rich, chocolatey, and definitely satisfied my sweet tooth.
 
I will say I had to cook it for an additional 10 minutes than the recipe called for. And they did not come out of the pan very nicely and kind of crumbled. But they were tasty!

title: Testing Two AI Art Models: Gemini vs. Flux.1-dev
text:
Testing Two AI Art Models: Gemini vs. Qwen Image
I tried running the same prompts through two different image generation models — Google’s Gemini 2.5 Flash and the open-source Flux.1-dev — just to see how they’d interpret the same ideas.
For the “cozy café on a rainy street corner” prompt, Gemini added people into the scene. They looked a little animated, almost hazy, which gave it a softer, storybook vibe. Flux.1-dev went the opposite direction: darker streets, no people, and warm glowing lights from inside the café. It felt moodier, maybe more atmospheric.
 
Then I tried “a sunflower field in Van Gogh style.” Here Gemini really nailed the painterly feel — thick strokes, swirly textures, very recognizable Van Gogh energy. Flux.1-dev leaned more cartoon-like, but still clearly borrowed from Van Gogh’s palette and angle.
 
It’s worth noting that Flux.1-dev is open source, which means it’s more hackable, customizable, and shaped by the community. Gemini feels a bit more polished and accurate out of the box, but less flexible under the hood. Together, the differences highlight what’s exciting (and sometimes unpredictable) about experimenting with AI art tools.

title: Using Gemini to Plan 4 Days in Spain
text:
Planning my time in Zaragoza, Spain

My parents, my grandma, and I are going to Spain in January and have not planned the portion of the trip where we are in Zaragoza. We are visiting my mom’s cousin there and want to hit the major landmarks. To help my mom plan, I decided to enlist Gemini to give us recommendations to look into. Here is the prompt I gave it

I am planning a trip to Spain and have 4 days in Zaragoza. We already have accommodations in the city. We get there on January 18th in the afternoon and leave on the 22nd in the morning. I am not too familiar with the city so would like recommendations on how to fill our time there. Keep in mind we do not have a car but could potentially rent one. Any recommendations for what to inside and outside the city?

Here was Gemini’s Response:

Day 1: Arrival & The “El Tubo” Experience * Afternoon Arrival: Settle into your accommodation. If you are near the center, start with a walk to Plaza del Pilar, one of the largest pedestrian squares in Europe. * Evening: Head to El Tubo, a famous maze of narrow alleys filled with tapas bars. * Tip: Try the famous mushrooms at El Champi or the croquettes at Doña Casta.
Day 2: Mudéjar Architecture & Roman Roots * Morning: Visit the Basilica del Pilar. It’s free to enter, but pay the small fee to take the elevator up the tower for the best panoramic view of the city and the Ebro River. * Late Morning: Walk 2 minutes to La Seo Cathedral. While the Basilica is more famous, many locals prefer La Seo for its stunning mix of Gothic and Mudéjar (Islamic-influenced) styles. * Afternoon: Follow the Roman Route. Zaragoza was the Roman city Caesaraugusta. Visit the Roman Theatre (the most impressive ruin) and the Forum Museum located underground.
Day 3: The Aljafería & Modern Art * Morning: Aljafería Palace. This 11th-century Islamic palace is a UNESCO World Heritage site and arguably the most important Moorish building outside of Andalusia. * Note: It currently houses the regional parliament, so booking tickets online in advance is highly recommended. * Afternoon: Visit the Goya Museum. Francisco de Goya was born just outside the city, and this museum houses a significant collection of his engravings and paintings. * Alternative: If you prefer modern art, the IAACC Pablo Serrano is a striking building with great contemporary exhibits.
Day 4: Day Trip (No Car Needed) You can easily see incredible sites outside the city using Spain’s efficient train (AVE) or bus network: * Option A: Alquézar (Bus/Tour): Often cited as one of Spain’s most beautiful medieval villages, famous for its “footbridges” walk along the river. * Option B: Monasterio de Piedra (Bus): A stunning natural park filled with waterfalls and a 12th-century monastery. There is a direct bus from the Zaragoza Delicias station that takes about 2 hours. * Option C: Belchite (Bus): For history buffs, the ruins of “Old Belchite” (destroyed in the Civil War) serve as a haunting “ghost town” memorial.

I thought this was a great response. Gemini also offered to but the recommendations into a sheet so I clicked on it and it generated this sheet:

The sheet was not exactly that much more helpful but the overall recommendations were great. I especially liked the options for taking bus tours instead of renting a car. I think we will definitely look into booking the bus tour to the monastery and Alquézar because the pictures online look beautiful.
 
I compared the output to TripAdvisor:

Basílica de Nuestra Señora del Pilar
Palacio de la Aljafería
Catedral del Salvador (La Seo)
Plaza del Pilar
Museo del Teatro de Caesaraugusta (Roman Theatre)
Acuario de Zaragoza (Freshwater Aquarium)
Museo Goya - Colección Ibercaja
Parque Grande José Antonio Labordeta
El Tubo (The famous tapas district)
Puente de Piedra (Stone Bridge)
Mercado Central de Zaragoza
Museo del Foro de Caesaraugusta (Roman Forum Museum)

There were some overlap but Gemini was also able to give me things to do outside of the city. Overall, as a tool to narrow down the overwhelming amount of information out there, Gemini was great. I got a lot of direct leads that saved me time and probably a lot of stress behind the wheel.

title: Book Reflection #4
text:
This chapter discusses how LLMs can act as a GPS to navigate the massive amount of information available around us. This includes informing any decision making, verifying information correctness, and increasing creativity and productivity. This chapter emphasizes again how AI can give us better opportunities when leveraged effectively and should not be feared.
A metaphor I found interesting in the book was “knowledge fog” which described how the current state of the internet is an information overload or a fog. Google give you a list of links to information thats practically endless. The authors claim that LLMs can act as a path through the fog by synthesizing large amounts of data.
One point I didn’t quite agree with was using LLMs as a truth verifier. I think that LLMs are still not at the point where I trust the output enough to claim it is true on topics I’m not well-versed in. LLMs still hallucinate and can provide misinformation in some cases. However, I think they are great resources to converse with so could help individuals make more informed decisions.




Chapter 8 discusses a unique intersection between technology and governance systems. Specifically, it talks about how techology is becoming increasingly intertwined with these legal systems including law and regulations. Additionally, it mentions how AI may lead us to rethink and refactor our existing human systems because of outdated beliefs and ethics. The chapter once agains gives an example of how AI and humans can work together to improve society as a whole.
The authors mention how “law is code” which implies that legal agreements could eventually be self-executing. They also mention how AI could help produce a more proactive system through computer vision, turning minor violations like public intoxication or illegal parking into zero-tolerance offenses. This, to me, felt a bit dystopian. I think our laws right now disproportionately affect certain demographics because of societal biases and deep-seated discrimination. By enforcing laws even more, specific groups of people will likely be affected much more than others. I am a proponent of using AI to fix these societal issues before having them enforce any laws.
