title: Book Reflection #5
text:
Chapter 9 talks about how AI will support more complicated human endeavors by enhancing human agency. This teamwork will lead to even greater impact than before because of AI being a supertool. One specific concept mentioned was an “agentic AI mesh” where multiple AI agents work together without much human involvement. Hoffman suggests that this “mesh” allows individual humans to act as the “CEO” of their own personal department of AI experts. These autonomous systems will require good guardrails and guidelines in order to stay on track and be productive in technological innovation. Ultimately, the goal is to move from AI as a simple assistant to AI as a collaborative network that can handle complex, multi-step projects independently.




This chapter highlights the need for the U.S. to prioritize AI so that it can stay a world leader. The government can utilize AI to modernize their governance, improve public services, and drive economic growth. It relates AI to other national infrastructure like highways or the internet which can put the U.S. in another era of prosperity. The authors argue that if the U.S. fails to lead in AI development, it risks ceding the global standard for ethics and safety to other nations with different values. The end of the chapter emphasizes the importance of being cautious when implementing AI in the government because of risks of job displacement, monopoly, and ethical use. The authors frame AI as a tool that America needs to invest in for the betterment of the nation, suggesting that a “National AI Strategy” is as vital to the 21st century as the Space Race was to the 20th.



This chapter is a culmination of themes previously mentioned in the book. Specifically, how AI can help humans build a better future and how people should actively participate in shaping AI’s trajectory. Hoffman emphasizes that the future isn’t something that just “happens” to us, but something we co-author through our choices today. A large portion of the chapter is also on certain challenges that should be guarded against like ethical issues, amplifying inequalities, and corrosion of critical thinking. The book concludes with an optimistic call to action, reminding readers that while the risks are real, the greatest risk of all is failing to use AI to solve our most urgent global problems.

title: Book Reflection #1
text:
The book starts off with a bit of history on technologies and their role in humanity. They talk about the printing press, the telephone, the Model T, etc and how people have always had skepticism and negative feelings towards these emerging technologies, claiming that they will replace humans in industry or make people less productive in society. In contrast, society has lower unemployment rates and more productivity today. They make claims of how technological progress is inevitable because of the innate collaborative and competitive nature of humans. I thought this was a good opening that set the scene of how people have reacted in the past so that the reader can see the connection with how certain people feel about AI today.



Now, the authors set the stage of post-COVID-19 chaos, with inflation concerns and big tech lay-offs. Then, in November of 2022 OpenAI released ChatGPT without advanced notice or hype but became popular because of it’s unprecedented performance: versatile and incredibly knowledgable. It created a wave of urgency within the tech space because big tech companies felt they fell behind. The government also became skeptical and held hearings on AI. Then, a tangent on how AI works and undermines the true “intelligence” it has.
The authors also cover how these AI systems, namely ChatGPT, were adopted very quickly and had immediate impact on society. The main ideas covered human control and agency and how AI systems can increase agency when used efficiently. AI should enhance human decisions and not replace them and we are the people who should take that initiative.



This chapter drew on ideas from the book 1989 by George Orwell and concerns over technological surveillance and how they have always existed. The authors highlighted how these concerns have often been exagerated and also incorporated a real story of fears over a data center managed by the goverment in the 1960s. They also cited that access to computers and the internet led to more individual empowerment rather than opression.
I enjoyed this chapter because I was learning new things about the history of technology in the U.S. that I didn’t know previously. I also think this was a pretty strong argument by citing past examples of people having fears of new technology but ended up being fine. The past fears of government control ended up being overpowered by the democratization of knowledge and information from the people.




So far, I think the book does a great job of connecting past reactions to new technologies with current attitudes toward AI. I’ve enjoyed how it uses historical context to show that fears about innovation often fade as society adapts and benefits from progress. Overall, it’s made me think more critically about how human agency and collaboration shape the role of technology in our lives.

title: Planning a California Road Trip
text:
I’m heading out on a road trip with a local Californian: I land in the Bay Area (SFO) on December 9, and we will be leaving from there on the 10th. We’ll need to be at Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) by about 9 a.m. on December 17. We’re ready for adventure and open to sleeping in the car for a couple of nights (if safe) and finding some budget-friendly stays along the way. We also want to squeeze in a day in San Diego and will stay with family in Oxnard, CA for a night or two.
I used ChatGPT to help me plan the route, stops, and lodging options. Here’s how it went:



I’m planning a road trip in California: I go to SFO in California on December 9th and will be leaving from the Bay on December 10th. We need to be at LAX airport by around 9am on December 17th. I’ll be traveling with one other person. We are willing to sleep in the car for a couple of nights (if the area is safe), but we’d also like to find relatively cheap places to stay overnight along the way. We also want to include a day-visit to San Diego if feasible, and we’ll stay for a night or 2 with family in Oxnard, CA. Please help me plan the route, suggest where to stop each night, safe car-sleep or cheap lodging tips, and how to budget for accommodation. Also highlight how to prompt you (the LLM) to get best results for road-trip planning.




The LLM gave me some images to start:

Then outlined the trip it had planned:



Route shape: Bay Area → Monterey/Carmel (scenic stop) → US-101 via San Luis Obispo → Santa Barbara → Oxnard (family nights) → Los Angeles → San Diego day-trip → back to LA (sleep near LAX on 12/16).
Big Sur caution: Highway 1 through Big Sur still has long-term closures; plan to enjoy the northern Big Sur viewpoints from Carmel/Monterey, then cut back to US-101 for the through-drive south. Always check Caltrans trip-day status. (SFGATE)
Car-sleep rules: CA rest areas allow up to 8 hours; camping is prohibited. Look for posted “8 HOUR PARKING” signs (Caltrans/MUTCD). (Legal Information Institute)
Walmart overnights: Allowed case-by-case by store manager (varies by city ordinances). Ask the specific store. (DAT)
Train option for San Diego: If you don’t want to fight I-5 traffic, the Amtrak Pacific Surfliner runs frequent LA↔︎SD trains (walkable stations). (Amtrak)


Dec 9 – Arrive SFO Crash wherever you’re staying in the Bay. If you want a budget SF option night-of: Hostelling International (dorms/private). (HI USA)
Dec 10 – Bay Area → Monterey/Carmel → San Luis Obispo/Pismo (sleep)

Morning: Drive HWY-1 to Carmel, Point Lobos pull-offs, Bixby vista if open from the north (turn around before closures), then hop to US-101 via Salinas/Prunedale. (SFGATE)
Sleep (choose one):

Very cheap car-camp (legal): CA rest area on US-101 (e.g., Camp Roberts near San Miguel) — max 8 hrs. (yelp.com)
Budget motel in San Luis Obispo/Pismo (often $60–$120 range in December). (expedia)


Dec 11 – SLO/Pismo → Santa Barbara → Oxnard (family)

Roll the coast on US-101. Afternoon in Santa Barbara; sunset in Channel Islands Harbor after you land in Oxnard. (channelislandsharbor.org)
Sleep: with family (1 of 1–2 free nights).

Dec 12 – Oxnard (family day)

Options: Harbor walk, kayak, or consider a Channel Islands boat if seas/coast weather look good (Island Packers runs park/ferry & wildlife trips). (Island Packers)
Sleep: with family (2 of 2 free nights, or just 1 if you prefer more LA time).

Dec 13 – Oxnard → Los Angeles (sleep)

Short hop. Explore LA neighborhoods or beaches.
Sleep: budget motel/hostel in LA or a permitted rest area stop along a freeway outside dense neighborhoods if you want a second car-sleep night (observe posted limits). (Legal Information Institute)

Dec 14 – LA → San Diego (sleep in SD or return to LA) Two good ways:

Drive I-5 early (2–3 hrs off-peak), or
Train Pacific Surfliner from LA Union Station → San Diego (walkable to transit/Balboa Park connections). (Amtrak)


SD highlights for a single day: La Jolla Cove (sea lions/seals), Balboa Park, Old Town. (La Jolla is a protected area; keep a respectful distance from wildlife.) (Tripadvisor)
Sleep: Either inexpensive SD hostel/motel or back in LA (see budget section sources). (expedia)

Dec 15 – Back to LA (if you slept in SD)

Extra LA sightseeing or beach day.
Sleep: LA area.

Dec 16 – Stage for LAX

Keep this night near LAX/El Segundo so the 9am arrival on the 17th is easy. Choose a basic motel/airport hotel; car-sleep is not recommended near the airport due to city ordinances and parking enforcement.
Sleep: LAX-area lodging.

Dec 17 – Fly from LAX ~9am

Return the car and roll out.


Legal, safe car-sleep options (max 2 nights total like you wanted):

Caltrans Rest Areas (8-hr limit; not camping): Pull in late, leave early, use well-lit, busy facilities. Example on your route: Camp Roberts on US-101. (Legal Information Institute)
Some Walmarts allow overnight by manager permission—always ask inside; varies by city. (DAT)

Ultra-budget paid stays:

Municipal campground: Veterans Memorial Park (Monterey) is first-come, first-served, inexpensive, and central for your 12/10 evening if you want a camp vibe. Vehicle length limits apply. (Monterey)
Hostels (HI USA) in SF/LA/SD: dorm beds and some privates; great for meeting travelers. (HI USA)
Motels (SLO/LA/SD): December is generally cheaper on the Central Coast (SLO) with frequent sub-$120 nights. (expedia)


You’ll likely cover 7 nights total (nights of 12/10–12/16), with 1–2 free in Oxnard family housing and up to 2 car-sleep nights. Here are two realistic mixes:

Frugal mix: 2 car-sleep nights (free), 2 family nights (free), 3 paid nights @ ~$90–$140/room ⇒ $270–$420 + tax total. (SLO/LA winter prices often fall in this band.) (expedia)
Comfort mix: 1 car-sleep night, 2 family nights, 4 paid nights @ ~$110–$160 ⇒ $440–$640 + tax.

(Hostel dorms can be $30–$60/pp; privates more. Great way to trim costs in SF/LA/SD.) (HI USA)


Check road status same-day (winter slides/repairs on Hwy 1 can change). Caltrans site/QuickMap are the source of truth. (California Road Information)
Rest areas = “rest,” not camping. CA regs: no more than 8 hours in any 24-hour period. Move on after a night. (Legal Information Institute)
Ask before parking overnight at private lots (Walmart, etc.); manager permission is key. (DAT)
San Diego wildlife (La Jolla): observe from a distance; it’s a protected marine area. (Airial)
Airport morning: Sleep within 15–20 minutes of LAX on 12/16, and return your car with a buffer.



Channel Islands outing from Oxnard (half- or full-day via Island Packers). Weather-dependent, magical. (Island Packers)
Santa Barbara mission/shoreline walk en route.
Pacific Surfliner for a chill, scenic San Diego day without LA freeways. (Amtrak)






I thought that Chat did a good job proposing an idea. It provided me a lot of information to think about for my planning and it was helpful that it provided specific links to go follow. I particularly liked the day-by-day break down part and the safety + logistics tips part. I was unaware of the policies surrounding sleeping at rest stops and in Walmart parking lots (which seems a little sketch).
I forgot to tell Chat that we would have our own car and would not have to rent. I wanted to get a more succinct plan so I asked it to make a detailed day-by-day itinerary:

Lodging / Notes

—

≤ 1 h

Stay near LAX (El Segundo/Inglewood motel $120 avg)


Dec 17 (Wed)

—

I’m excited. This trip feels very doable with our timeline. Using ChatGPT to map out the plan saved me a ton of mental work and gave me a structure to build off of.

title: Planning a California Road Trip
text: I’m planning a road trip in California: I go to SFO in California on December 9th and will be leaving from the Bay on December 10th. We need to be at LAX airport by around 9am on December 17th. I’ll be traveling with one other person. We are willing to sleep in the car for a couple of nights (if the area is safe), but we’d also like to find relatively cheap places to stay overnight along the way. We also want to include a day-visit to San Diego if feasible, and we’ll stay for a night or 2 with family in Oxnard, CA. Please help me plan the route, suggest where to stop each night, safe car-sleep or cheap lodging tips, and how to budget for accommodation. Also highlight how to prompt you (the LLM) to get best results for road-trip planning.

title: Planning a California Road Trip
text:
The LLM gave me some images to start:

Then outlined the trip it had planned:



Route shape: Bay Area → Monterey/Carmel (scenic stop) → US-101 via San Luis Obispo → Santa Barbara → Oxnard (family nights) → Los Angeles → San Diego day-trip → back to LA (sleep near LAX on 12/16).
Big Sur caution: Highway 1 through Big Sur still has long-term closures; plan to enjoy the northern Big Sur viewpoints from Carmel/Monterey, then cut back to US-101 for the through-drive south. Always check Caltrans trip-day status. (SFGATE)
Car-sleep rules: CA rest areas allow up to 8 hours; camping is prohibited. Look for posted “8 HOUR PARKING” signs (Caltrans/MUTCD). (Legal Information Institute)
Walmart overnights: Allowed case-by-case by store manager (varies by city ordinances). Ask the specific store. (DAT)
Train option for San Diego: If you don’t want to fight I-5 traffic, the Amtrak Pacific Surfliner runs frequent LA↔︎SD trains (walkable stations). (Amtrak)


Dec 9 – Arrive SFO Crash wherever you’re staying in the Bay. If you want a budget SF option night-of: Hostelling International (dorms/private). (HI USA)
Dec 10 – Bay Area → Monterey/Carmel → San Luis Obispo/Pismo (sleep)

Morning: Drive HWY-1 to Carmel, Point Lobos pull-offs, Bixby vista if open from the north (turn around before closures), then hop to US-101 via Salinas/Prunedale. (SFGATE)
Sleep (choose one):

Very cheap car-camp (legal): CA rest area on US-101 (e.g., Camp Roberts near San Miguel) — max 8 hrs. (yelp.com)
Budget motel in San Luis Obispo/Pismo (often $60–$120 range in December). (expedia)


Dec 11 – SLO/Pismo → Santa Barbara → Oxnard (family)

Roll the coast on US-101. Afternoon in Santa Barbara; sunset in Channel Islands Harbor after you land in Oxnard. (channelislandsharbor.org)
Sleep: with family (1 of 1–2 free nights).

Dec 12 – Oxnard (family day)

Options: Harbor walk, kayak, or consider a Channel Islands boat if seas/coast weather look good (Island Packers runs park/ferry & wildlife trips). (Island Packers)
Sleep: with family (2 of 2 free nights, or just 1 if you prefer more LA time).

Dec 13 – Oxnard → Los Angeles (sleep)

Short hop. Explore LA neighborhoods or beaches.
Sleep: budget motel/hostel in LA or a permitted rest area stop along a freeway outside dense neighborhoods if you want a second car-sleep night (observe posted limits). (Legal Information Institute)

Dec 14 – LA → San Diego (sleep in SD or return to LA) Two good ways:

Drive I-5 early (2–3 hrs off-peak), or
Train Pacific Surfliner from LA Union Station → San Diego (walkable to transit/Balboa Park connections). (Amtrak)


SD highlights for a single day: La Jolla Cove (sea lions/seals), Balboa Park, Old Town. (La Jolla is a protected area; keep a respectful distance from wildlife.) (Tripadvisor)
Sleep: Either inexpensive SD hostel/motel or back in LA (see budget section sources). (expedia)

Dec 15 – Back to LA (if you slept in SD)

Extra LA sightseeing or beach day.
Sleep: LA area.

Dec 16 – Stage for LAX

Keep this night near LAX/El Segundo so the 9am arrival on the 17th is easy. Choose a basic motel/airport hotel; car-sleep is not recommended near the airport due to city ordinances and parking enforcement.
Sleep: LAX-area lodging.

Dec 17 – Fly from LAX ~9am

Return the car and roll out.


Legal, safe car-sleep options (max 2 nights total like you wanted):

Caltrans Rest Areas (8-hr limit; not camping): Pull in late, leave early, use well-lit, busy facilities. Example on your route: Camp Roberts on US-101. (Legal Information Institute)
Some Walmarts allow overnight by manager permission—always ask inside; varies by city. (DAT)

Ultra-budget paid stays:

Municipal campground: Veterans Memorial Park (Monterey) is first-come, first-served, inexpensive, and central for your 12/10 evening if you want a camp vibe. Vehicle length limits apply. (Monterey)
Hostels (HI USA) in SF/LA/SD: dorm beds and some privates; great for meeting travelers. (HI USA)
Motels (SLO/LA/SD): December is generally cheaper on the Central Coast (SLO) with frequent sub-$120 nights. (expedia)


You’ll likely cover 7 nights total (nights of 12/10–12/16), with 1–2 free in Oxnard family housing and up to 2 car-sleep nights. Here are two realistic mixes:

Frugal mix: 2 car-sleep nights (free), 2 family nights (free), 3 paid nights @ ~$90–$140/room ⇒ $270–$420 + tax total. (SLO/LA winter prices often fall in this band.) (expedia)
Comfort mix: 1 car-sleep night, 2 family nights, 4 paid nights @ ~$110–$160 ⇒ $440–$640 + tax.

(Hostel dorms can be $30–$60/pp; privates more. Great way to trim costs in SF/LA/SD.) (HI USA)


Check road status same-day (winter slides/repairs on Hwy 1 can change). Caltrans site/QuickMap are the source of truth. (California Road Information)
Rest areas = “rest,” not camping. CA regs: no more than 8 hours in any 24-hour period. Move on after a night. (Legal Information Institute)
Ask before parking overnight at private lots (Walmart, etc.); manager permission is key. (DAT)
San Diego wildlife (La Jolla): observe from a distance; it’s a protected marine area. (Airial)
Airport morning: Sleep within 15–20 minutes of LAX on 12/16, and return your car with a buffer.



Channel Islands outing from Oxnard (half- or full-day via Island Packers). Weather-dependent, magical. (Island Packers)
Santa Barbara mission/shoreline walk en route.
Pacific Surfliner for a chill, scenic San Diego day without LA freeways. (Amtrak)

title: Getting Started with GPT4All
text:
Local LLMs are great when you want privacy, offline access, or the freedom to experiment without an API key. GPT4All is a friendly desktop app that lets you download and chat with hundreds of open models—from lightweight 3–8B assistants to niche coding or multilingual variants—right on your machine.
Installing the GPT4All app typically takes less than 5 minutes and once you launch it you can explore all the models they have to offer.







Best for: Tiny footprint, quick drafts, “always-on” helper on modest hardware.
Why it’s neat: Strong quality for its size; offered in 4K and 128K context variants.





Best for: General chat + reasoning at 7B scale; a solid baseline many people compare against.
Note: Community-standard workhorse; the Instruct flavor is a tuned chat model.





Best for: Multilingual tasks & coding-friendly chat with modern tuning.
Why it’s neat: Qwen2/2.5 report strong results across language understanding, generation, coding, and reasoning.





Best for: Longer context experiments and a widely supported 8B option.
Trade-off: A step up in memory/compute vs. 7B, but you get a newer training run and longer context window.






1) Start with your hardware.

Low RAM / older CPU? Begin with Phi-3 Mini (Q4) for responsiveness.
8–16 GB+ and patient? Try Mistral 7B Instruct (Q4/Q5) or Qwen2(.5) 7B Instruct for a quality bump.
Room to spare / longer docs? Experiment with Llama-3.1-8B Instruct (longer context).

2) Match the task.

General writing/assistant: Mistral 7B, Llama-3.1-8B.
Small + snappy: Phi-3 Mini.
Multilingual/coding: Qwen2/2.5 7B.

3) Pick a quantization.

Q4 loads faster and uses less RAM; Q5 trades a bit more memory for a quality bump.
In GPT4All, you’ll see these as different downloads of the same model—grab Q4 first, upgrade if you need more fidelity.

4) Keep an eye on context length.

If you paste long readings or transcripts, prefer models that ship 8K–128K contexts (e.g., Phi-3 128K, Llama-3.1-8B).





GGUF is a compact binary format optimized for local inference (fast loading/saving) used by runners like llama.cpp. You’ll see many models offered as *.gguf downloads in GPT4All’s browser and on Hugging Face. You don’t have to do anything special—just download and run—but it’s why these models feel snappy on CPU.





It feels slow. Try a smaller model (3–4B), a more aggressive quantization (Q4), or reduce context length in GPT4All settings.
Out-of-memory errors. Close other heavy apps, use Q4, or choose a smaller parameter count.
macOS specifics. Official docs currently list Monterey 12.6+ as the target for the macOS build, and performance is best on Apple Silicon; CPU-only still works—just pick smaller models.
Need lots of models? GPT4All’s browser surfaces a huge catalog so you can trial multiple flavors side-by-side.

title: ChatGPT Helps Me Cut My Roommate’s Hair
text:
Cutting hair is one of those things that seems simple until you’re the one actually holding the scissors. My roommate asked me to trim and layer her long, wavy hair and I told her I’d give it a go.
So naturally, I opened ChatGPT-5 and asked it how to guide me step-by-step.




My friend asked me to cut her hair. How would you recommend I do it? She has long hair that’s slightly wavy with layers



ChatGPT gave a beginner-friendly overview: tools needed, the “golden rules,” and a safe method using sectioning or the “unicorn cut.” It emphasized trimming very conservatively, keeping symmetry, and using point-cutting to soften the ends.
It told me not to use kitchen scissors. Unfortunately, those were the only scissors I had.

I uploaded a picture of my roommate’s hair from the back. I clarified that I didn’t want to do the unicorn cut.






I don’t think I want to do a unicorn cut so I think I’ll section it and cut it.




ChatGPT analyzed the photo and confirmed:
The hair type (long, wavy)
Uneven ends
Recommended a 3-section method
Told me exactly how to trim the bottom, middle, and top sections safely
It was like having a virtual hairstylist supervise.

I sent another picture after I clipped her hair into multiple sections.






It outlined the steps to go from the current photo including what to do for the bottom, middle, and top sections and then doing the side + face-framing and cross-check. It also made the comment:


Just keep these rules in mind:

Bottom = blunt(ish) trim
Middle = longest/softest layers
Top = lightest, shortest layers
Point-cut everything except the bottom baseline


It adjusted its instructions based on the exact setup in the image.

I did the length trim and sent another picture of the result.






Now I want to do layers.




This is where ChatGPT-5 really shined. It told me exactly how to layer based on the photo:
Release the middle section
Cut the “guide” layer
Elevate at 45°
Trim only 1/2 inch
Use vertical point-cutting to avoid harsh lines
Then move to the top section and add only light layering

The layering was the part that I was most worried for but I followed the instructions and think my roommates hair turned out great!
Would I trust ChatGPT to cut my own hair? … Probably not.
Would I use it again to cut someone else’s hair? Absolutely.

title: Prompting ChatGPT for marathon training plan
text:
I’ve been running consistently, but I’ve never had a formal marathon plan tailored to my goals and timeframe. Hiring a coach can be expensive, and online plans are usually one-size-fits-all.
So, I decided to experiment: what if ChatGPT 5 could be my running coach?



I wanted to have the final plan customized for me based on my current fitness and lifestlye. I started off by asking ChatGPT 5 what sort of information it wanted from me in order to make my training plan.

User: I want you to be my running coach to help me train for the 2025 Philadelphia Marathon which is in 2 months. Can you give me a list of questions that you would ask me in order to formulate a customized training plan for me?

ChatGPT: Perfect! To create a customized 2-month training plan for the 2025 Philadelphia Marathon, I’d want to get a full picture of your background, goals, lifestyle, and constraints. Here’s a list of questions I’d ask you as your “coach”:
🏃 Running Background

What is your current weekly mileage?
What’s the longest run you’ve completed recently?
Have you ever run a marathon before? If so, what was your time/experience like?
Do you have recent race times for shorter distances (5K, 10K, half marathon)?
Do you typically run on roads, tracks, or trails?

🎯 Goals & Expectations

What is your primary goal for the Philadelphia Marathon — finish strong, hit a specific time, or qualify for something (e.g., Boston)?
Do you have a target pace in mind for race day?
What’s more important to you: speed, endurance, or simply enjoying the experience?

🏋️ Strength & Cross Training

Do you currently do strength training or cross training (cycling, swimming, yoga, etc.)?
Are you open to incorporating strength/mobility sessions into your plan?

⏰ Schedule & Lifestyle

How many days per week can you realistically commit to running?
Do you prefer morning, afternoon, or evening runs?
Do you have any upcoming travel, work, or school commitments that may affect training?

🩺 Health & Injury History

Have you had any past or current injuries (knees, shins, ankles, hips, etc.)?
Do you have any health concerns I should keep in mind (e.g., asthma, anemia, nutrition issues)?

🥗 Fueling & Recovery

How’s your nutrition and hydration routine right now?
Do you have experience practicing fueling (gels, chews, hydration) on long runs?
How many hours of sleep do you typically get per night?

🌦 Race-Day Specifics

Have you run in Philadelphia before, or are you familiar with the marathon course?
Do you have gear preferences (shoes, watch, hydration belt/vest)?

💡 Personal Motivation

What motivates you most: following a structured plan, listening to your body, or running with others?
What do you hope to get out of this marathon beyond just finishing (confidence, health, community, fun)?


It gave me 22 questions to answer! I answered each of them to the best of my ability with hopes of having a very in-depth and tailored training plan.



8-Week Philadelphia Marathon Training Plan
(Starting Monday, Sept 15, 2025 → Race Day Sunday, Nov 23, 2025)

Key: - MP = Marathon Pace (8:00–8:15/mi) - Tempo = Half Marathon pace (~7:55–8:00/mi) - Intervals = 10K pace (~7:40–7:50/mi) or 5K pace (~6:55–7:05/mi) - Easy/aerobic runs = comfortable conversational pace (~9:00–9:30/mi) - Long runs include fueling practice + hydration - Rest = rest day or optional cross training (bike, swim, yoga)



This experiment showed me how AI can make training feel more accessible.
While it won’t replace years of coaching expertise, it’s a surprisingly motivating and structured tool.
For now, ChatGPT is my new running buddy — and hopefully, it’ll help me cross the finish line in Philadelphia this fall.

💡 Personal Motivation

What motivates you most: following a structured plan, listening to your body, or running with others?
What do you hope to get out of this marathon beyond just finishing (confidence, health, community, fun)?


It gave me 22 questions to answer! I answered each of them to the best of my ability with hopes of having a very in-depth and tailored training plan.

This experiment showed me how AI can make training feel more accessible.
While it won’t replace years of coaching expertise, it’s a surprisingly motivating and structured tool.
For now, ChatGPT is my new running buddy — and hopefully, it’ll help me cross the finish line in Philadelphia this fall.

title: Comparing AI Detection Results on Different Models
text:
Comparing AI Detection Results on ChatGPT 5.0, Gemini 2.5 Flash, and local DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B.
I gave the 3 models the same prompt: Explain how photosynthesis works in plants (3-5 sentences).
I then used zeroGPT.com to analyze each of their responses. The results were as follows:

ChatGPT 5.0:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose (sugar) and oxygen. This takes place mainly in the chloroplasts of plant cells, where the green pigment chlorophyll absorbs light energy. The light energy powers chemical reactions that split water molecules, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. The glucose made provides energy and building material for the plant’s growth and survival.
AI Detector Result:

Gemini 2.5 Flash:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy to create their own food. Plants absorb water through their roots and carbon dioxide (CO^2) through tiny pores in their leaves called stomata. Using chlorophyll to capture energy from sunlight, these raw materials are transformed into glucose (a sugar for energy) and oxygen (O^2). The oxygen is then released as a byproduct, making the process vital for life on Earth.
AI Detector Result:

DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B (did not keep it 3-5 sentences):
Photosynthesis is a process where plants convert sunlight into chemical energy to fuel their growth and survival. This occurs primarily in chloroplasts, which contain chlorophyll giving them their green color. The process consists of two main stages: the light-dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle.
In the light-dependent reactions (PSII), water molecules are split using ATP synthase, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. This step also produces ATP and NADPH, energy carriers essential for the next stage.
The Calvin cycle (PC) involves fixing carbon dioxide into organic compounds through enzyme-driven reactions in the stroma of chloroplasts. Using ATP and NADPH, CO2 is converted into glucose, providing plants with the energy they need to grow and develop. This process ensures that plants can synthesize their own food using sunlight as an energy source.
AI Detector Result:


Just by copy and pasting the outputs from the models, the AI detector correctly identified each of the responses as 100% AI generated. However, I wanted to see what it would say about other likely non-AI generated responses. I went to Wikipedia and to National Geographic and copied the first couple lines of the article on photosynthesis. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photosynthesis and https://education.nationalgeographic.org/resource/photosynthesis/).
I also went to Quora and grabbed an explanation from 12 years ago (https://www.quora.com/What-is-photosynthesis-and-how-does-it-work).

Wikipedia:
Photosynthesis is a system of biological processes by which photopigment-bearing autotrophic organisms, such as most plants, algae and cyanobacteria, convert light energy — typically from sunlight — into the chemical energy necessary to fuel their metabolism. The term photosynthesis usually refers to oxygenic photosynthesis, a process that releases oxygen as a byproduct of water splitting. Photosynthetic organisms store the converted chemical energy within the bonds of intracellular organic compounds (complex compounds containing carbon), typically carbohydrates like sugars (mainly glucose, fructose and sucrose), starches, phytoglycogen and cellulose. When needing to use this stored energy, an organism's cells then metabolize the organic compounds through cellular respiration.
AI Detector Result:

National Geographic:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to create oxygen and energy in the form of sugar. During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) from the air and soil. Within the plant cell, the water is oxidized, meaning it loses electrons, while the carbon dioxide is reduced, meaning it gains electrons. This transforms the water into oxygen and the carbon dioxide into glucose. The plant then releases the oxygen back into the air, and stores energy within the glucose molecules.
AI Detector Result:

Quora:
Photosynthesis occurs in two stages. In the first stage, light-dependent reactions or light reactions capture the energy of light and use it to make the energy-storage molecules ATP (Adenosine Thiosulphate) and NADPH. During the second stage, the light-independent reactions use these products to capture and reduce carbon dioxide. Most organisms that utilize photosynthesis to produce oxygen use visible light to do so, although at least three use infrared radiation.
AI Detector Result:


Both of the articles were also classified 100% as AI-generated. I am not convinced that these articles were actually written by AI, but there is potential they were. I am very confident that the Quora answer was not AI generated, given that it was posted 12 years ago, yet the detector found that it was almost 70% AI generated.
Overall, I think this AI detector may be overconfident in its detection of AI vs. Human. In practice, this makes them unreliable for truly distinguishing between human and machine-written content.
